awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Impact of Teaching Function in an Engineering Design Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project will help improve the ability of engineering students to design systems and processes to meet consumer needs. Continued innovation in science and engineering is critical to national security, economic growth, and achieving a sustainable society. It is crucial that engineering education move beyond teaching only engineering science and analysis: engineers must be able to design, create, and innovate. Functional modeling is a tool that improves engineering design skills, but little empirical data can be found that demonstrates how functional modeling improves engineering designs or how to teach functional modeling in a way that makes students better designers. The overall objective of this proposal is to determine the impact of teaching function on engineering students' design synthesis abilities. Results will improve the ability of engineering education programs to develop engineering graduates that are able to effectively innovate and develop new products to meet emerging national needs.

Most engineering design texts discuss and prescribe functional recognition and some form of modeling as a step in the engineering design process, yet it is only anecdotal evidence that suggests that students who are taught functional modeling during the design process become better designers. This project will investigate the relationships between functional modeling skill and design outcomes by measuring the ability of students to (1) explore the solution space during ideation, (2) generate high quality designs, and (3) represent and understand engineered systems. This work will test three hypotheses: (1) Functional modeling skills increase the quantity, variety, quality, and novelty of design alternatives during the concept generation phase of a design task; (2) Functional modeling skills increase the quality of a final design in a capstone course as judged by a group of faculty and industry experts; and (3) Functional modeling skills increase students' ability to understand and represent a system. The project includes efforts to disseminate the results of this work to the broader engineering education community.

por.por_cntn:
Engineers use qualitative reasoning in analysis and design. This project focused on functional modeling, one type of qualitative reasoning tool used during early phase engineering design to explore the anticipated transformations of energies, materials, and information that constitute all engineered systems.   

Functional modeling is often taught as a tool for linking design requirements to a system representation during early phases of the engineering design process in engineering design textbooks, but little empirical data clearly demonstrates that functional modeling improves engineering designs or that teaching functional modeling makes students better designers. This project sought to explore the relationship between learning functional modeling and students' design thinking abilities. To accomplish this goal, more reliable and higher validity approaches to measuring one's functional modeling skills were developed as were instruments for assessing the impact of learning functional modeling on one's ability to understand and represent engineered systems (in other words, one's systems thinking ability). 

First, to understand one's learning of functional modeling, rubrics for assessing functional model quality were significantly improved to obtain higher reliability with both expert and novice users. This rubric was used to assess students' functional modeling ability longitudinally. Students in an undergraduate program who are taught functional modeling as sophomores maintain their understanding of function as seniors, though aptitude at modeling declines. Additionally, students who learned to generate functional models recognize the organizational structure of the system and understand that energy, material, and information transformations must exist together to allow the system to function effectively, and when engineering students are taught functional modeling as opposed to simply listing functions, they identify more transformations of energies, materials, and information necessary for system operation.   

Second, to evaluate how functional modeling instruction provides a mental framework for enhancing the understanding and representation of engineering systems, an extensible Mental Model Instrument for measuring one's internal representations of external systems (termed mental models) and scoring rubric was developed. The Mental Model Instrument allows investigation of the effects of pedagogical interventions such as learning functional modeling on systems understanding. A study involving graduate engineering students has confirmed that functional understanding increased the completeness of students' mental model representations of common engineering systems, attributed to a stronger framework for system communication, and verified the mental model elicitation method. In a follow-up study with graduate engineering students using the Mental Model Instrument, practice effects are not observed indicating applicability for studies exploring the result of pedagogical interventions on students' ability to articulate their mental models.    

To explore the broader applicability of the methods developed in this research, studies were performed with first-year engineering students as well as with non-engineering undergraduate students. For first-year engineering students, receiving a lecture on product functionality as well as completion of a product disassembly activity targeting one of the systems in the Mental Model Instrument are shown to improve students' articulation of some mental models in the instrument. Additionally, a study of non-engineering undergraduates' mental models of common systems demonstrates that for these non-engineering students improved mental model articulation occurs following instruction on functional modeling and product teardown activities. This study demonstrates that the Mental Model Instrument can be completed successfully by non-STEM majors as well as the potential for measurement of improvement in technological literacy.  

This work provides initial evidence that functional modeling provides a useful framework for assisting students in organizing their knowledge about engineering systems. Instruments were refined and developed for measuring functional modeling and system understanding. An effective approach for teaching functional modeling was also shown. Results demonstrate the need for more work exploring different approaches to functional modeling and their impacts on system understanding, especially over long periods of time as engineers develop knowledge.
